question: A queue follows the FIFO (First In, First Out) principle.
In a queue, elements can only be inserted at the front.
A queue is considered empty when the front and rear pointers are equal.
A circular queue allows efficient memory usage by reusing vacant spaces at the front.
A priority queue always follows the FIFO principle.
A queue can be implemented using arrays or linked lists.
The rear pointer in a queue moves forward when an element is deleted.
A double-ended queue (Deque) allows insertion and deletion from both ends.
A stack and a queue are identical data structures.
A queue can never be full if it is implemented using a linked list.
In a queue, deletion is performed from the rear end.
A queue data structure is commonly used in task scheduling systems.
A priority queue removes elements in the order they were inserted.
A circular queue prevents overflow if there is available space at the front.
A linear queue allows elements to be inserted from any position.
The main disadvantage of a linear queue is that it may lead to memory wastage.
A queue can be used to simulate customer service lines.
A queue can be used in operating systems for CPU scheduling.
Deque stands for Double Queue.
A circular queue is also known as a ring buffer.
